security: Revealing Paneque's assignment to AMRUG-5 and details of his recruitment, training, and termination with the CIA exposes operational methods and compromises potential re-use as an asset. Additionally, the memo describing Paneque's psychological assessment and shortcomings ('least intelligent...shortcomings seem to outweigh his assets') could damage his reputation and compromise future intelligence work. Finally, the 1977 report stating 'Paneque participated in Cuban exile activities in New York area in 1962 and later registered in ISR & Dept of Army in August 1962' reveals a timeline of his activities and potential sources.
summary: Collection of documents pertaining to Victor Paneque, including background information, reports of his activities, and assessments of his suitability as a CIA asset, covering the period from 1959 to 1977.
summary_one_paragraph: This collection of documents, dated primarily from 1960 to 1977, focuses on Victor Paneque, a figure involved in anti-Castro activities and later recruited by the CIA. The documents include reports suggesting Paneque was a potential Castro agent, messages detailing his early activities in Miami with anti-Castro groups like Alianza de Liberacion, and cables indicating his arrest in Cuba. Later documents detail Paneque's CIA recruitment as a radio operator, psychological assessments indicating he was 'least intelligent' but experienced, his assignment to AMRUG-5, and eventual termination with a recommendation for future re-use. The collection also contains information on Paneque's participation in Cuban exile activities in New York and a 1972 report identifying him as a member of the PCC militia and Defense Committee in Cuba.
title: Victor Paneque File
